review_title: I know it's sort of a cop out to blame management - but really, blame the lab management
job_title: Medical Technologist in Mount Pleasant, PA
pros: Lab is starting to skew younger, hoping that brings some much-needed change.  Benefits if full time are pretty good
cons: Awful work/life balance.   Awful benefits if anything other than full time - have to "earn" benefits working part time at full time hours for a year.  Yes, that includes overnights, weekends, and holidays, with a garbage shift differential.  Some coworkers are a neurotic mess - there is something very, very wrong with coworkers who live, eat, sleep, breathe work and management not stomping that out (keeps them from having to do any work!).   Tell me why techs are doing inventory and ordering supplies, doing a majority of the testing and calibration on new machines (that the department supervisor hardly planned for), and helping to craft the schedule sometimes, and for absolutely no increase in pay or any recognition whatsoever?  Analyzer goes down and stuff hits the fan?  Well, management can't help, it's time for literally all of them to go to lunch! I have never dealt with such lazy, cliquey management before in my life. Just a very weird, poorly-managed lab in general, network wide.

review_title: Loved the work not the company.
pros: Job security. (They keep bad employees too).  There are some good co-workers.  Christmas bonus=free meal in the cafeteria.  Almost every year a 2% raise if you jump through all the hoops.
cons:
1.Those bad employees that get to stay and even get better treatment than those who follow policy and are always going above and beyond. 
2. Unstable schedule.  One day you start at 4am the next day could be 930am and then a midnight. ( The exception, those bad employees)
3. They do not count your minor child (who lives with you)  being admitted to a hospital as an excusable absence. Even if it's the ICU  Ridiculous
4. It's always changing.  Just when you get the new procedures down they change them.    Same goes for Human Resource policy.  We jokingly called these the change of the day. Rightfully so since there is probably 250 changes a year. (I wish I where joking)  These changes range from testing requirements to 403 retirement matching.
